'''Carlos Alcaraz Garfia''' ({{IPA-es|ˈkarlos alkaˈɾaθ}};<ref>{{cite web|title=The pronunciation by Carlos Alcaraz himself|url=https://www.atptour.com/-/media/player-names/carlos-alcaraz-player-name-2021.mp3|work=ATPWorldTour.com|access-date=19 July 2023|archive-date=12 April 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230412223748/https://www.atptour.com/-/media/player-names/carlos-alcaraz-player-name-2021.mp3|url-status=live}}</ref> born 5 May 2003) is a Spanish professional [[tennis]] player. He has been ranked as high as [[List of ATP number 1 ranked singles tennis players|world No. 1]] in men's singles by the [[Association of Tennis Professionals]] (ATP). As of December 19, 2023, he was ranked 2nd in the world by the [[Association of Tennis Professionals ]] (ATP). Alcaraz has won twelve [[ATP Tour]]-level singles titles, including two [[Grand Slam (tennis)#Tournaments|major titles]] (at the [[2022 US Open – Men's singles|2022 US Open]] and [[2023 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles|2023 Wimbledon Championships]]) and four [[ATP Tour Masters 1000|Masters 1000]] titles. Following his win at the 2022 US Open, Alcaraz became the youngest man and the first teenager in the [[Open Era]] to top the singles rankings, at 19 years, 4 months, and 6 days old.<ref name="ATP1">{{cite web |title=Alcaraz becomes youngest world No. 1 in Pepperstone ATP rankings history |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-climbs-to-world-no-1-us-open-2022 |website=ATP Tour |access-date=12 September 2022 |date=11 September 2022 |archive-date=12 September 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220912000636/https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-climbs-to-world-no-1-us-open-2022 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-ruud-us-open-2022-final |title=Alcaraz wins US Open title & rises to world No. 1 |website=ATP Tour |access-date=12 September 2022 |date=11 September 2022 |archive-date=12 September 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220912002152/https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-ruud-us-open-2022-final |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite web |title=Carlos Alcaraz Youngest Year-End ATP No. 1 Presented By Pepperstone In History |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/carlos-alcaraz-year-end-no-1-2022 |access-date=26 November 2022 |website=ATP Tour |archive-date=16 November 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221116111255/https://www.atptour.com/en/news/carlos-alcaraz-year-end-no-1-2022 |url-status=live }}</ref>

As a junior, Alcaraz was ranked as high as world No. 22 and won two titles on the [[ITF Junior Circuit]]. After turning professional in 2018, he won three titles on the [[ITF Men's World Tennis Tour]] and four on the [[ATP Challenger Tour]] and broke into the top 100 in rankings in May 2021. Two months later, Alcaraz won his first ATP title at the [[2021 Croatia Open Umag – Singles|Croatia Open]], an [[ATP Tour 250|ATP 250]] tournament. He later entered the top 50 after reaching the quarterfinals at the following US Open and won the year end [[2021 Next Generation ATP Finals|Next Generation ATP Finals]] in [[Milan]]. After winning his first [[ATP Tour 500|ATP 500]] title at the [[2022 Rio Open – Singles|Rio Open]] in February 2022, Alcaraz won his first Masters 1000 title at the [[2022 Miami Open – Men's singles|Miami Open]] and his second ATP 500 title at the [[2022 Barcelona Open Banc Sabadell – Singles|Barcelona Open]] in April, propelling him into the top 10. In September 2022, Alcaraz defeated [[Casper Ruud]] in the US Open final to win his first major singles title. In May 2023, he was awarded the [[Laureus World Sports Award for Breakthrough of the Year|Laureus World Breakthrough of the Year]] award. In July 2023, Alcaraz won Wimbledon, defeating seven-time and defending champion [[Novak Djokovic]] in the final to claim his second major singles title. {{TOC limit|2}}

==Early life==
Carlos Alcaraz Garfia was born on 5 May 2003, in [[El Palmar, Murcia]], Spain, to parents Carlos Alcaraz González and Virginia Garfia Escandón. He has three siblings.

Alcaraz started playing tennis at the age of four at the Real Sociedad Club de Campo de Murcia (Royal Society Murciashire Club), where his father was the tennis academy director. Alcaraz' father was a former professional player, but stopped playing when he couldn't afford to any longer. In 2018, he moved to [[Villena]] to begin training at [[Juan Carlos Ferrero]]'s Equelite JC Ferrero Sport Academy.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.equelite.com/jcferrerero-nuevo-coach-carlos-alcaraz/ |title=Juan Carlos Ferrero será el nuevo coach de Carlos Alcaraz |date=7 August 2018 |website=Equelite JC Ferrero Sport Academy |language=es |access-date=11 May 2022 |archive-date=26 June 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220626171617/https://www.equelite.com/jcferrerero-nuevo-coach-carlos-alcaraz/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2023/may/26/born-to-be-no-1-tennis-the-making-of-carlos-alcaraz|title='This boy was born to be No 1': the making of Carlos Alcaraz|website=[[The Guardian]]|first=Tumaini|last=Carayol|date=27 May 2023|access-date=7 November 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230601065251/https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2023/may/26/born-to-be-no-1-tennis-the-making-of-carlos-alcaraz|archive-date=1 June 2023|url-status=live}}</ref>

==Professional career==
===2020: ATP debut===
In February 2020, at the age of 16, Alcaraz made his ATP main-draw debut at the [[2020 Rio Open|Rio Open]] after receiving a wildcard for the singles main draw. There, he defeated [[Albert Ramos Viñolas]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.tennisworldusa.org/tennis/news/ATP_Tennis/81432/carlos-alcaraz-grabs-2020-rio-open-wild-card-for-an-atp-debut/ |title=Carlos Alcaraz grabs 2020 Rio Open wild card for an ATP debut |website=Tennis World USA |date=13 December 2019 |access-date=15 February 2020 |archive-date=15 February 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200215222514/https://www.tennisworldusa.org/tennis/news/ATP_Tennis/81432/carlos-alcaraz-grabs-2020-rio-open-wild-card-for-an-atp-debut/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Alcaraz was defeated in the second round by [[Federico Coria]].

===2021: First title, Next-Gen Finals champion, top 35===
[[File:Carlos Alcaraz.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Alcaraz at the [[2021 French Open]]]]

At age 17, Alcaraz made it to the main draw of the [[2021 Australian Open – Men's singles|Australian Open]], making him the youngest participant in the men's singles.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://sportsfinding.com/alcaraz-follows-in-the-footsteps-of-djokovic-nadal-and-federer/78180/ |title=Alcaraz follows in the footsteps of Djokovic, Nadal and Federer |date=15 January 2021 |access-date=9 February 2021 |archive-date=15 February 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210215002650/https://sportsfinding.com/alcaraz-follows-in-the-footsteps-of-djokovic-nadal-and-federer/78180/ |url-status=live }}</ref> He won his [[Grand Slam (tennis)|Grand Slam tournament]] debut defeating fellow qualifier [[Botic van de Zandschulp]] in straight sets before losing in the second round to [[Mikael Ymer]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-australian-open-2021-tuesday |title=17-Year-Old Carlos Alcaraz Wins Grand Slam Debut at Australian Open |access-date=9 February 2021 |archive-date=14 February 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214125326/https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-australian-open-2021-tuesday |url-status=live }}</ref>

Alcaraz became the youngest match winner in the [[Madrid Open (tennis)|Madrid Open's]] history, defeating [[Adrian Mannarino]] as a wildcard and breaking then-18-year-old [[Rafael Nadal]]'s record from 2004. In the second round, he lost to five-time champion Nadal on Alcaraz's 18th birthday.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-mannarino-madrid-2021-monday |title=Carlos Alcaraz Sets Rafael Nadal Clash in Madrid |access-date=4 May 2021 |archive-date=5 May 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210505195536/https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-mannarino-madrid-2021-monday |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-madrid-2021-monday-reaction |title=Alcaraz on 'Dream' Nadal Clash: 'It's the Best Birthday Present' |access-date=4 May 2021 |archive-date=4 May 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210504040630/https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-madrid-2021-monday-reaction |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.tennisworldusa.org/tennis/news/Rafael_Nadal/97643/rafael-nadal-loses-madrid-open-age-milestone-to-17yearold-carlos-alcaraz/ |title=Rafael Nadal loses Madrid Open age milestone to 17-year-old Carlos Alcaraz |date=4 May 2021 |access-date=4 May 2021 |archive-date=7 May 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210507041141/https://www.tennisworldusa.org/tennis/news/Rafael_Nadal/97643/rafael-nadal-loses-madrid-open-age-milestone-to-17yearold-carlos-alcaraz/ |url-status=live }}</ref>
By winning the biggest title of his career until then at the [[2021 Open de Oeiras III]] Challenger tournament, he entered the top 100 as the youngest player at the age of 18 on 24 May 2021.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-2021-oeiras-challenger-title |title=Carlos Alcaraz Claims Historic Fourth Challenger Crown |access-date=23 May 2021 |archive-date=1 June 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210601170732/https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-2021-oeiras-challenger-title |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.tennis-tourtalk.com/74206/alcaraz-triumphs-at-oeiras-open-challenger |title=Alcaraz Triumphs at Oeiras Open Challenger |date=22 May 2021 |access-date=22 May 2021 |archive-date=22 May 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210522175712/https://www.tennis-tourtalk.com/74206/alcaraz-triumphs-at-oeiras-open-challenger |url-status=dead }}</ref>

At the [[2021 French Open – Men's singles|French Open]], Alcaraz reached the third round of a major for the first time in his career by defeating [[Nikoloz Basilashvili]].

In July 2021, he reached his first ATP final at the [[2021 Croatia Open Umag – Singles|2021 Croatia Open Umag]], defeating top seed [[Albert Ramos Viñolas]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/ramos-vinolas-alcaraz-gasquet-altmaier-umag-2021-sf |title=Carlos Alcaraz Makes History in Umag, Reaches First ATP Tour Final |access-date=27 August 2021 |archive-date=10 November 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211110200001/https://www.atptour.com/en/news/ramos-vinolas-alcaraz-gasquet-altmaier-umag-2021-sf |url-status=live }}</ref> He then won his maiden ATP title by defeating [[Richard Gasquet]] and becoming the youngest tour-level champion since 18-year-old [[Kei Nishikori]] won the Delray Beach Open in 2008. Alcaraz was the youngest Spaniard to win an ATP Tour title since Nadal claimed his first trophy in [[Sopot]] in 2004.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-gasquet-umag-2021-final |title=18-Year-Old Carlos Alcaraz Wins First ATP Tour Title in Umag |access-date=27 August 2021 |archive-date=11 June 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220611082959/https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-gasquet-umag-2021-final |url-status=live }}</ref>

At [[2021 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles|Wimbledon]], he lost in the second round to [[Daniil Medvedev]]. At the [[2021 Winston-Salem Open|Winston-Salem Open]], Alcaraz reached the round of 16 defeating qualifier [[Alexei Popyrin]], and his second tour-level quarterfinal of the season defeating fourth seed [[Márton Fucsovics]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-tiafoe-winston-salem-2021-wednesday |title=Alcaraz Rebounds to Foil Fucsovics' Bid in Winston-Salem |access-date=27 August 2021 |archive-date=27 August 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210827031103/https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-tiafoe-winston-salem-2021-wednesday |url-status=live }}</ref> He defeated [[Marcos Giron]] to reach the semifinals,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://apnews.com/article/sports-tennis-us-open-tennis-championships-winston-salem-36e3b51a216b02e05d6f75949ef77779 |title=Ivashka, Ruusuvuori, Ymer advance in Winston-Salem Open |website=[[Associated Press]] |date=27 August 2021 |access-date=27 August 2021 |archive-date=28 August 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210828070412/https://apnews.com/article/sports-tennis-us-open-tennis-championships-winston-salem-36e3b51a216b02e05d6f75949ef77779 |url-status=live }}</ref> where he lost to [[Mikael Ymer]].

At the [[2021 US Open – Men's singles|US Open]], Alcaraz defeated world No. 3 [[Stefanos Tsitsipas]] in a fifth-set tiebreak to reach the fourth round in the biggest win of his career.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/lifestyle/sports/alcaraz-upsets-tsitsipas-reach-us-open-fourth-round-2021-09-03/ |title=Alcaraz upsets Tsitsipas to reach U.S. Open fourth round |work=Reuters |date=4 September 2021 |last1=Keating |first1=Steve |access-date=4 September 2021 |archive-date=11 June 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220611093944/https://www.reuters.com/lifestyle/sports/alcaraz-upsets-tsitsipas-reach-us-open-fourth-round-2021-09-03/ |url-status=live }}</ref> At 18 years of age, Alcaraz became the youngest man in a major fourth round since 17-year-old [[Andrei Medvedev (tennis)|Andrei Medvedev]] at the [[1992 French Open – Men's singles|1992 French Open]], and the youngest man in the US Open fourth round since 17-year-old [[Michael Chang]] and 18-year-old [[Pete Sampras]] in [[1989 US Open – Men's singles|1989]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/tsitsipas-alcaraz-us-open-2021-friday |title=Carlos Alcaraz Records Biggest Career Win, Shocks Stefanos Tsitsipas in US Open Thriller |access-date=4 September 2021 |archive-date=4 September 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210904001025/https://www.atptour.com/en/news/tsitsipas-alcaraz-us-open-2021-friday |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/32141025/daniil-medvedev-cruises-pablo-andujar-fourth-round-us-open |title=Alcaraz, 18, stuns Tsitsipas; Tiafoe tops Rublev |date=3 September 2021 |access-date=4 September 2021 |archive-date=4 September 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210904010845/https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/32141025/daniil-medvedev-cruises-pablo-andujar-fourth-round-us-open |url-status=live }}</ref> He then reached the quarterfinals by defeating qualifier [[Peter Gojowczyk]]. Alcaraz became the youngest US Open men's quarterfinalist in the [[Open Era]], the youngest at the tournament since 18-year-old [[Thomaz Koch]] in [[1963 U.S. National Championships – Men's singles|1963]], and the youngest Grand Slam tournament men's singles quarterfinalist since 18-year-old Michael Chang at the [[1990 French Open – Men's singles|1990 French Open]]. He then lost to [[Félix Auger-Aliassime]] via retirement in the second set in the quarterfinals after injuring his leg.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.tennis.com/news/articles/the-latest-fernandez-19-reaches-us-open-women-s-semis |title=The Latest: Alcaraz says leg muscle made him stop at Open |access-date=8 September 2021 |archive-date=11 June 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220611083455/https://www.tennis.com/news/articles/the-latest-fernandez-19-reaches-us-open-women-s-semis |url-status=live }}</ref>

At the [[Erste Bank Open]], Alcaraz defeated world No. 7 [[Matteo Berrettini]], his second win over a top-10 player,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-berrettini-zverev-felix-vienna-2021-friday |title=Carlos Alcaraz Upsets Berrettini in Vienna Classic, Reaches SFS |work=ATP Tour |access-date=29 October 2021 |archive-date=12 June 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220612145925/https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-berrettini-zverev-felix-vienna-2021-friday |url-status=live }}</ref> and became the youngest player in the top 35 on 1 November. During his [[2021 Rolex Paris Masters – Singles|Paris Masters]] run, Alcaraz defeated French wildcard [[Pierre-Hugues Herbert]] in three thrilling sets in the first round.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.tennisworldusa.org/tennis/news/Tennis_Interviews/104476/carlos-alcaraz-reacts-to-surviving-thriller-versus-pierrehugues-herbert-in-paris-/ |title=Carlos Alcaraz reacts to surviving thriller versus Pierre-Hugues Herbert in Paris |date=2 November 2021 |access-date=5 November 2021 |archive-date=11 May 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220511111210/https://www.tennisworldusa.org/tennis/news/Tennis_Interviews/104476/carlos-alcaraz-reacts-to-surviving-thriller-versus-pierrehugues-herbert-in-paris-/ |url-status=live }}</ref> He then defeated [[Jannik Sinner]] in straight sets in the second round, his third win over a top-10 player.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-sinner-paris-2021-wednesday |title=Carlos Alcaraz Stops Jannik Sinner's Nitto ATP Finals Tilt |access-date=5 November 2021 |archive-date=3 November 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211103183139/https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-sinner-paris-2021-wednesday |url-status=live }}</ref> In the third round, he was defeated by [[Hugo Gaston]] in straight sets.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/gaston-wins-17-straight-points-to-beat-alcaraz-paris-2021 |title=Hugo Gaston Wins 17 Straight Points to Beat Alcaraz Paris 2021 |access-date=5 November 2021 |archive-date=10 May 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220510221049/https://www.atptour.com/en/news/gaston-wins-17-straight-points-to-beat-alcaraz-paris-2021 |url-status=live }}</ref>

At the [[Next Generation ATP Finals|Next Gen ATP Finals]], Alcaraz defeated [[Brandon Nakashima]], [[Juan Manuel Cerúndolo]], and [[Holger Rune]] in the round-robin stage. He beat [[Sebastian Baez]] in the semifinal, and [[Sebastian Korda]] in the final.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-rune-milan-2021-tuesday |title=Carlos Alcaraz Downs Rune in Milan |access-date=13 November 2021 |archive-date=12 June 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220612113013/https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-rune-milan-2021-tuesday |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-nakashima-milan-2021-wednesday |title=Alcaraz Secures SF Berth in Milan |access-date=13 November 2021 |archive-date=11 June 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220611093944/https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-nakashima-milan-2021-wednesday |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-cerundolo-milan-2021-thursday |title=Ruthless Carlos Alcaraz Sinks Juan Manuel Cerundolo in Milan |access-date=13 November 2021 |archive-date=13 November 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211113000935/https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-cerundolo-milan-2021-thursday |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-baez-milan-2021-friday |title=Carlos Alcaraz Sets Sebastian Korda Showdown in Milan |access-date=13 November 2021 |archive-date=11 June 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220611083451/https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-baez-milan-2021-friday |url-status=live }}</ref>

===2022: First major, youngest world No. 1, and year-end No. 1===
{{Main article|2022 Carlos Alcaraz tennis season}}

Seeded for the first time in a major at No. 31, Alcaraz reached the third round of the [[2022 Australian Open – Men's singles|Australian Open]] before losing in five sets to [[Matteo Berrettini]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-australian-open-2022-monday-reaction |title=What Carlos Alcaraz Has Done Quicker Than the Big Three | ATP Tour | Tennis |access-date=19 January 2022 |archive-date=19 January 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220119053743/https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-australian-open-2022-monday-reaction |url-status=live }}</ref>

[[File:2023RGCarlosAlcaraz (cropped).jpg|thumb|right|upright|Alcaraz at the [[2023 French Open]]]]On 7 January, Alcaraz announced his withdrawal from the [[2023 Australian Open|Australian Open]] due to a hamstring injury he suffered in his right leg while training.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cbssports.com/tennis/news/wta-requiring-resolution-of-peng-shuai-case-for-womens-tennis-tournaments-return-to-china/ |title=Australian Open 2023: World No. 1 Carlos Alcaraz withdraws from Grand Slam tournament due to leg injury |website=cbssports.com |date=7 January 2023 |access-date=7 January 2023 |archive-date=7 January 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230107033406/https://www.cbssports.com/tennis/news/wta-requiring-resolution-of-peng-shuai-case-for-womens-tennis-tournaments-return-to-china/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Following the tournament, he lost the world No. 1 ranking to the champion [[Novak Djokovic]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/djokovic-pepperstone-atp-rankings-30-january-2023#:~:text=The%20Serbian%20has%20returned%20to,extending%2010th%20Australian%20Open%20crown. |title=Djokovic Returns To No. 1, Mover Of Week |date=30 January 2023 |publisher=[[Association of Tennis Professionals]] |access-date=8 February 2023 |archive-date=8 February 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230208002730/https://www.atptour.com/en/news/djokovic-pepperstone-atp-rankings-30-january-2023#:~:text=The%20Serbian%20has%20returned%20to,extending%2010th%20Australian%20Open%20crown. |url-status=live }}</ref> He held the ranking for a total of 20 weeks.

In his first tournament for the 2023 season at the [[Golden Swing]] in South America, Alcaraz won his seventh title at the [[2023 Argentina Open – Singles|Argentina Open]], defeating second seed [[Cameron Norrie]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-norrie-buenos-aires-2023-final |title=Carlos Alcaraz Wins Buenos Aires Title in Season Debut |publisher=ATP Tour |access-date=26 February 2023 |archive-date=26 February 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230226215456/https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-norrie-buenos-aires-2023-final |url-status=live }}</ref> Defending his title at the [[2023 Rio Open – Singles|Rio Open]], he reached back to back finals where he played against Norrie again, but lost in three sets.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-jarry-rio-2023-sf |title=Alcaraz Extends Perfect Season, Sets Norrie Rematch with Rio SF Comeback |publisher=ATP Tour |access-date=26 February 2023 |archive-date=26 February 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230226050008/https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-jarry-rio-2023-sf |url-status=live }}</ref> Alcaraz was additionally scheduled to play in [[2023 Abierto Mexicano Telcel|Acapulco]] in the month of February, but withdrew prior to the tournament after suffering another hamstring injury.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.espn.com.au/tennis/story/_/id/35755117/top-seed-carlos-alcaraz-acapulco-hamstring-strain |title=Top seed Carlos Alcaraz out of Acapulco with hamstring strain |date=1 March 2023 |publisher=[[ESPN]] |agency=Reuters|access-date=4 March 2023 |archive-date=4 March 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230304073940/https://www.espn.com.au/tennis/story/_/id/35755117/top-seed-carlos-alcaraz-acapulco-hamstring-strain |url-status=live }}</ref>

In [[2023 Miami Open – Men's singles|Miami]] where Alcaraz was the defending champion, he reached the semifinals having not dropped a set defeating [[Facundo Bagnis]], [[Dušan Lajović]], 16th seed [[Tommy Paul (tennis)|Tommy Paul]] and ninth seed [[Taylor Fritz]]. This time he lost to Jannik Sinner in three sets.<ref>{{cite web |title=Sinner Storms Back To Beat Alcaraz In Miami SF, Ending Spaniard's No. 1 Reign – Tennis |website=ATP Tour |date=1 April 2023 |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-sinner-miami-2023-sf |access-date=4 April 2023 |archive-date=3 April 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230403133737/https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-sinner-miami-2023-sf |url-status=live }}</ref> He dropped to No. 2 in the rankings having not been able to defend his previous year title points.<ref>{{cite web |title=Jannik Sinner wins the point of the year, then ends Carlos Alcaraz's hopes for a Sunshine Double |website=Tennis.com |date=1 April 2023 |url=https://www.tennis.com/news/articles/the-point-of-the-year-by-jannik-sinner-and-carlos-alcaraz |access-date=4 April 2023 |archive-date=2 April 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230402045713/https://www.tennis.com/news/articles/the-point-of-the-year-by-jannik-sinner-and-carlos-alcaraz |url-status=live }}</ref>

Alcaraz was scheduled to play at the [[2023 Monte-Carlo Masters|Monte-Carlo Masters]] the following week, but withdrew due to post-traumatic arthritis in his left hand and muscular discomfort in his spine.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tennis.com/news/articles/nadal-alcaraz-pull-out-of-clay-court-monte-carlo-masters|title=Rafael Nadal, Carlos Alcaraz pull out of Monte Carlo Masters|website=[[Tennis.com]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=4 April 2023|access-date=9 September 2023|archive-date=24 May 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230524225356/https://www.tennis.com/news/articles/nadal-alcaraz-pull-out-of-clay-court-monte-carlo-masters|url-status=live}}</ref> He began the European clay court swing at the [[2023 Barcelona Open Banc Sabadell – Singles|Barcelona Open]]; defeating [[Stefanos Tsitsipas]] in the final, he successfully defended his title without dropping a set.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.skysports.com/tennis/news/12110/12864374/barcelona-open-carlos-alcaraz-beats-stefanos-tsitsipas-to-retain-title|title=Barcelona Open: Carlos Alcaraz beats Stefanos Tsitsipas to retain title|publisher=[[Sky Sports]]|date=23 April 2023|access-date=9 September 2023|archive-date=24 May 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230524235345/https://www.skysports.com/tennis/news/12110/12864374/barcelona-open-carlos-alcaraz-beats-stefanos-tsitsipas-to-retain-title|url-status=live}}</ref> He won his tenth career title at the [[2023 Mutua Madrid Open – Men's singles|Madrid Open]] again as the defending champion, defeating lucky loser [[Jan-Lennard Struff]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-madrid-2023-final-reaction |title=Carlos Alcaraz Makes History with 10th Title | ATP Tour | Tennis |access-date=8 May 2023 |archive-date=8 May 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230508000728/https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-madrid-2023-final-reaction |url-status=live }}</ref> At the next clay court tournament, the [[2023 Italian Open – Men's singles|Rome Masters]], Alcaraz earned the opportunity to clinch the No. 1 ranking from Novak Djokovic just by playing his second round match. However, he would be upset in the third round by the world No. 135 [[Fabian Marozsan]] in straight sets, in what [[Jon Wertheim]] labelled the biggest upset of the year.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-marozsan-rome-2023-monday |title=Fabian Marozsan Beats Carlos Alcaraz in Rome Upset | ATP Tour | Tennis |access-date=22 May 2023 |archive-date=22 May 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230522152536/https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-marozsan-rome-2023-monday/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.si.com/tennis/2023/05/17/carlos-alcarazs-italian-open-upset-is-a-blessing-in-disguise|title=Carlos Alcaraz's Italian Open Upset Is a Blessing in Disguise|first=Jon|last=Wertheim|magazine=[[Sports Illustrated]]|date=17 May 2023|access-date=9 September 2023|archive-date=10 October 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231010192049/https://www.si.com/tennis/2023/05/17/carlos-alcarazs-italian-open-upset-is-a-blessing-in-disguise|url-status=live}}</ref>

At the [[2023 French Open – Men's singles|2023 French Open]], Alcaraz advanced to the semifinals. In a highly anticipated match, he was defeated by Novak Djokovic in four sets, after suffering cramps at the onset of the third. Alcaraz and Djokovic had not played against each other in over a year, despite alternating between the world No. 1 ranking throughout 2023; Alcaraz would later claim the nerves of the occasion had partially led to his cramping. Djokovic regained the No. 1 ranking from Alcaraz, after he ultimately went on to win the tournament.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.espn.co.uk/tennis/story/_/id/37826198/novak-djokovic-beats-carlos-alcaraz-reaches-french-open-final | title=Djokovic beats cramping Alcaraz, into French final | date=9 June 2023 | access-date=12 June 2023 | archive-date=12 June 2023 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230612215311/https://www.espn.co.uk/tennis/story/_/id/37826198/novak-djokovic-beats-carlos-alcaraz-reaches-french-open-final | url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2023/jun/09/alcaraz-admits-french-open-semi-final-cramps-were-caused-by-nerves|title=Alcaraz says French Open semi-final cramps were caused by nerves|work=[[The Guardian]]|first=Tumaini|last=Carayol|date=10 June 2023|access-date=9 September 2023|archive-date=10 October 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231010192048/https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2023/jun/09/alcaraz-admits-french-open-semi-final-cramps-were-caused-by-nerves|url-status=live}}</ref>

[[Image:Carlos Alcaraz Wimbledon 2023 Gentlemen's Singles Trophy.jpg|thumb|right|150px|In 2023 Carlos Alcaraz won his first Wimbledon title.]] At the [[2023 Queen's Club Championships – Singles|Queen's Club Championships]], he recorded his first title on grass in only his third career grass court tournament, beating [[Alex de Minaur]] in the final. The tournament win in London also returned him to the world No. 1 in rankings.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2023/jun/25/alcaraz-wins-queens-favourite-for-wimbledon|title=Carlos Alcaraz wins Queen's and declares himself a 'favourite' for Wimbledon|first=Sean|last=Ingle|work=The Guardian|date=26 June 2023|access-date=15 July 2023|archive-date=6 July 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230706225946/https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2023/jun/25/alcaraz-wins-queens-favourite-for-wimbledon|url-status=live}}</ref> At the [[2023 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles|2023 Wimbledon Championships]], as the top seed, he reached the final following wins over [[Jérémy Chardy]], [[Alexandre Müller]], [[Nicolás Jarry|Nicolas Jarry]], [[Matteo Berrettini]], [[Holger Rune]], and [[Daniil Medvedev]]. In a monumental [[2023 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles final|match]], Alcaraz defeated Novak Djokovic in five sets, ending Djokovic's run to win a fifth consecutive title, and securing the No. 1 ranking. With this win, Alcaraz became the second player, after [[Andy Murray]], to defeat Djokovic in a Wimbledon final.<ref>{{cite web |title=Stat of the Day: Carlos Alcaraz ends longest Centre Court winning streak for first Wimbledon title |url=https://www.tennis.com/news/articles/stat-of-the-day-carlos-alcaraz-ends-longest-centre-court-winning-streak-djokovic |website=Tennis.com |access-date=17 July 2023 |archive-date=17 July 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230717180322/https://www.tennis.com/news/articles/stat-of-the-day-carlos-alcaraz-ends-longest-centre-court-winning-streak-djokovic |url-status=live }}</ref> Additionally, Alcaraz became the first non-"[[Big Four (tennis)|Big 4]]" player to win Wimbledon since [[Lleyton Hewitt]]'s victory in [[2002 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles|2002]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Gharib |first=Anthony |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/tennis/wimb/2023/07/16/novak-djokovic-carlos-alcaraz-wimbledon-mens-final-result/70417922007/ |title=Carlos Alcaraz wins Wimbledon, denies Novak Djokovic record 24th Grand Slam singles title |website=USA Today |date=July 16, 2023 |access-date=July 17, 2023 |archive-date=17 July 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230717061050/https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/tennis/wimb/2023/07/16/novak-djokovic-carlos-alcaraz-wimbledon-mens-final-result/70417922007/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

Losing in the quarterfinals of [[2023 National Bank Open – Men's singles|Toronto]] to [[Tommy Paul (tennis)|Tommy Paul]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/sports/tennis/de-minaur-shocks-medvedev-reach-semis-toronto-2023-08-11/|title=Alcaraz stunned by Paul in Toronto quarters|work=[[Reuters]]|first=Rory|last=Carroll|date=12 August 2023|access-date=20 November 2023}}</ref> Alcaraz would then lose to Djokovic in a rematch of their Wimbledon final, at the [[2023 Western & Southern Open – Men's singles|Cincinnati]] final. He lost in three sets, despite having a championship point in the second-set tiebreak. It was the longest ever best-of-three-sets ATP Masters final and the longest match in the tournament's history, at 3 hours and 49 minutes; Djokovic would praise it as "one of the toughest matches of [his] life".<ref>{{Cite web |last=McGrogan |first=Ed |date=2023-08-21 |title=Novak Djokovic saves championship point in thrilling Cincinnati final win over Carlos Alcaraz |url=https://www.tennis.com/news/articles/novak-djokovic-carlos-alcaraz-cincinnati-final-championship-point |access-date=2023-08-21 |website=Tennis.com |archive-date=21 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230821015125/https://www.tennis.com/news/articles/novak-djokovic-carlos-alcaraz-cincinnati-final-championship-point |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2023/aug/20/coco-gauff-karolina-muchova-cincinnati-open|title=Novak Djokovic overcomes Carlos Alcaraz to win Cincinnati title in instant classic|work=[[The Guardian]]|first=Tumaini|last=Carayol|date=21 August 2023|access-date=20 November 2023}}</ref> At the [[2023 US Open – Men's singles|2023 US Open]], where Alcaraz was looking to defend his grand slam title, he reached the semifinals having only dropped one set. However, he lost to [[2021 US Open – Men's singles|2021]] champion [[Daniil Medvedev]] in four sets.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2023/sep/09/daniil-medvedev-stuns-carlos-alcaraz-to-set-up-us-open-final-showdown-with-novak-djokovic|title=Daniil Medvedev stuns Carlos Alcaraz to set up US Open final showdown with Novak Djokovic|work=[[The Guardian]]|first=Tumaini|last=Carayol|date=9 September 2023|access-date=9 September 2023|archive-date=9 September 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230909040451/https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2023/sep/09/daniil-medvedev-stuns-carlos-alcaraz-to-set-up-us-open-final-showdown-with-novak-djokovic|url-status=live}}</ref> Alcaraz dropped to No. 2 in the rankings following the tournament, as [[Novak Djokovic]] was not defending any points.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/djokovic-muller-us-open-2023-monday|title=Djokovic's Devastating Start To US Open|publisher=[[Association of Tennis Professionals]]|date=29 August 2023|access-date=9 September 2023|archive-date=29 August 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230829074008/https://www.atptour.com/en/news/djokovic-muller-us-open-2023-monday|url-status=live}}</ref> He additionally withdrew from the [[2023 Davis Cup Finals|Davis Cup Finals]], citing tiredness.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/sports/tennis/alcaraz-withdraws-spains-davis-cup-team-2023-09-10/|title=Alcaraz withdraws from Spain's Davis Cup team|work=[[Reuters]]|date=10 September 2023|access-date=20 November 2023}}</ref>

Alcaraz entered the year-end indoor hardcourt season with the goal of gaining the year-end No. 1 ranking.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-beijing-2023-preview|title=Alcaraz: 'No. 1 Is One Of The Main Goals'|publisher=[[Association of Tennis Professionals]]|date=27 September 2023|access-date=7 November 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-shanghai-2023-preview|title=Alcaraz On No. 1 Battle: 'Djokovic Is On My Mind In Every Practice'|publisher=[[Association of Tennis Professionals]]|date=5 October 2023|access-date=7 November 2023}}</ref> However, in the Asian swing, he lost to Jannik Sinner in the semifinals of [[2023 China Open – Men's singles|Beijing]] for a second time in the season, and then to [[Grigor Dimitrov]] in the round of 16 at [[2023 Rolex Shanghai Masters – Singles|Shanghai]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/sports/tennis/medvedev-into-china-open-final-after-routine-win-over-zverev-2023-10-03/|title=Sinner powers past Alcaraz to book Beijing final with Medvedev|work=[[Reuters]]|date=4 October 2023|access-date=7 November 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.eurosport.com/tennis/atp-shanghai/2023/carlos-alcaraz-suffers-shock-defeat-to-grigor-dimitrov-in-latest-shanghai-masters-upset-i-knew-what-_sto9832953/story.shtml|title=CARLOS ALCARAZ SUFFERS SHOCK DEFEAT TO GRIGOR DIMITROV IN LATEST SHANGHAI MASTERS UPSET - 'I KNEW WHAT I HAD TO DO'|work=[[Eurosport]]|first=Ben|last=Southby|date=11 October 2023|access-date=7 November 2023}}</ref> He then withdrew from [[2023 Swiss Indoors|Basel]] due to injury,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-basel-2023-withdrawal|title=Alcaraz Withdraws From Basel|publisher=[[Association of Tennis Professionals]]|date=18 October 2023|access-date=7 November 2023}}</ref> and lost in his opening round at the [[2023 Rolex Paris Masters – Singles|Paris-Bercy Masters]] to [[Roman Safiullin]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-reaction-paris-2023|title=Alcaraz: 'A Lot Of Things To Improve'|publisher=[[Association of Tennis Professionals]]|date=31 October 2023|access-date=7 November 2023}}</ref> At the [[2023 ATP Finals – Singles|ATP Finals]] in [[Turin]], Alcaraz reached the semifinals after beating [[Andrey Rublev]] and Daniil Medvedev, and losing to [[Alexander Zverev]], in the round-robin stage. He would be defeated by eventual champion Novak Djokovic in straight sets, for a third time in the season.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.eurosport.com/tennis/atp-finals/2023/im-not-at-his-level-carlos-alcaraz-admits-unbelievable-novak-djokovic-is-superior-indoors-after-atp-_sto9889172/story.shtml|title='I'M NOT AT HIS LEVEL' - CARLOS ALCARAZ ADMITS 'UNBELIEVABLE' NOVAK DJOKOVIC IS SUPERIOR INDOORS AFTER ATP FINALS DEFEAT|first=Ben|last=Southby|date=19 November 2023|access-date=20 November 2023|work=[[Eurosport]]}}</ref> Ultimately, Alcaraz ended the season as the year-end world No. 2.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-ferrero-turin-2023-sf-reaction|title=Ferrero On Alcaraz's 'Extremely Good' Year|date=19 November 2023|access-date=20 November 2023|publisher=[[Association of Tennis Professionals]]}}</ref>

==Playing style==
Alcaraz is an [[All-court player|all-court]], [[All-rounder (tennis)|all-round]] tennis player, but primarily employs an aggressive baseline style of play, with an emphasis on a high winner count from his [[forehand]], typically his most reliable and potent shot. He can either hit his forehand flat and fast for winners from every court position, or add a great amount of topspin and margin over the net. He also possesses a well-rounded and more flat and lower net-clearance [[backhand]] groundstroke that he is able to redirect down the line for clean winners. His greatly disguised [[drop shot]] is key to his game, as he often combines the heaviness of his groundstrokes that pushes his opponents back into the court into a defensive position, with a drop shot that is often too well-placed and disguised to deal with. He has an impressive net-game with great drop volleys and drive volleys, and frequently serves-and-volleys on crucial points.<ref>{{Cite web |title='Carlos Alcaraz can serve and volley at...', says former ATP ace |date=14 January 2023 |url=https://www.tennisworldusa.org/tennis/news/Carlos_Alcaraz/126770/-carlos-alcaraz-can-serve-and-volley-at-says-former-atp-ace/ |access-date=4 July 2023 |archive-date=4 July 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230704205432/https://www.tennisworldusa.org/tennis/news/Carlos_Alcaraz/126770/-carlos-alcaraz-can-serve-and-volley-at-says-former-atp-ace/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

Alcaraz has a strong first serve for his mid-sized frame which is commonly around 115 to 120 mph and hit with average placement.<ref>{{Cite web |title=How Alcaraz's Scintillating Serve Toppled Djokovic's Return In The Wimbledon Final {{!}} |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-djokovic-wimbledon-2023-final-brain-game |access-date=18 August 2023 |archive-date=18 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230818230616/https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-djokovic-wimbledon-2023-final-brain-game |url-status=live }}</ref> Alcaraz has a reliable second serve, to which he can add topspin in order to get a high bounce off the court and either push back or get a weak return from closer-returning opponents. This serve typically reaches 150 to 170 km/h (93 to 106 mph).<ref>{{Cite web |title=CARLOS ALCARAZ VS. ALEX DE MINAUR {{!}} LONDON 2023 |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/scores/stats-centre/live/2022/403/MS001 |access-date=4 July 2023 |archive-date=4 July 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230704205433/https://www.atptour.com/en/scores/stats-centre/live/2022/403/MS001 |url-status=live }}</ref>

Alcaraz has earned acclaim for his athletic and physical traits. In particular, his direct sprints, counterattacking abilities, and an extremely high peak [[footspeed]] have garnered him comparisons to a young [[Rafael Nadal]]. He has been compared to [[Novak Djokovic]] for his assured lateral movement and court-coverage aided by physical splits and sliding through the court on defense, particularly on his backhand side where he is often able to neutralize his opponent's groundstroke aggression or drop shot attempts. Court coverage and exceptional touch have also been crucial in his success.{{citation needed|date=September 2022}} In particular he is known for his frequent use of the drop shot.
